title: Liverpool must repeat battling Chelsea performance against every team, says Georginio Wijnaldum
text:

Georginio Wijnaldum believes Liverpool have sent “an important message” to their Champions’ League rivals... but must now back it up with top-four level consistency. 
After a nightmare three Anfield defeats in a week trashed their hopes of any silverware this season, the Reds hit back with a fine display against runaway leaders Chelsea and were unlucky to only draw rather than take a much-needed victory. 
Midfielder Wijnaldum though, believes it shows his team are back to their intense best, and now he wants his team-mates to back it up by addressing their biggest weakness this season – against the less fancied teams. 
Liverpool visit struggling Hull at the weekend, and the Dutchman who scored their equaliser on Tuesday said of the battling draw against Chelsea: “Of course it was an important message. “But it is more important that we continue it. 
"We showed it against Manchester City (who they beat on New Year's Eve at Anfield) and in the next game (the 2-2 draw at relegation candidates Sunderland), we didn’t. It is important to carry on the way we did (against Chelsea) and get a few points, otherwise it was for nothing. 
“We played with aggression and passion and that is a good thing to go forward but we must ensure we do it in every game. That’s the most important thing. If you do it one game and then not the next, it will cost you points. We saw in January that if you are not sharp, if you don’t play how we used to play, it will cost us points.” Liverpool hopes were high as Wijnaldum's goal beat Man City... (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) ...but two days later they were held by lowly Sunderland... (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) ...now they go to Hull, days after ending honours-even with the champions-elect (Photo: Liverpool FC via Getty) 
Liverpool may have blown their title hopes in January – and their chances of a trophy too, after two disastrous Cup exits in the space of four days – but they still harbour top-four ambitions. 
To do that though, they must improve their record against the smaller clubs. 
While Jurgen Klopp's men have not lost in any of their clashes against top six rivals this season, they have dropped far too many points to sides Chelsea seem to dismiss with ease. 
While the Stamford Bridge club have lost only to the Reds, Arsenal and Spurs this season, Liverpool have failed to beat a number of teams in the bottom half of the table, including Bournemouth, Sunderland, Swansea, West Ham, Southampton and Burnley.
